greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Shanks's array d_{a,n} (a >= 1, n >= 1) that generalizes the tangent numbers, read by antidiagonals upwards.
reference: D. Shanks. "Generalized Euler and Class Numbers." Math. Comput. 21, 689-694, 1967. Math. Comput. 22, 699, 1968.
link: Lars Blomberg, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..5050
D. Shanks, Generalized Euler and class numbers, Math. Comp. 21 (1967), 689-694; 22 (1968), 699. [Annotated scanned copy]
mathematica: amax = nmax = 10; km0 = 10; Clear[dd]; L[a_, s_, km_] := Sum[JacobiSymbol[ -a, 2k+1]/(2k+1)^s, {k, 0, km}]; d[1, n_, km_] := 2(2n-1)! L[-1, 2n, km] (2/Pi)^(2n) // Round; d[a_ /; a>1, n_, km_] := (2n-1)! L[-a, 2n, km] (2a/ Pi)^(2n)/Sqrt[a] // Round; dd[km_] := dd[km] = Table[d[a, n, km], {a, 1, amax}, {n, 1, nmax}]; dd[km0]; dd[km = 2km0]; While[dd[km] != dd[km/2, km = 2km]]; A235606 = dd[km]; Table[A235606[[ a-n+1, n]], {a, 1, amax}, {n, 1, a}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 05 2016 *)
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jan 22 2014
